body:
Thanks for raising this issue.

Seems like this code doesn't take any passing parameter:
```
https://github.com/apache/incubator-pinot/blob/master/pinot-tools/src/main/java/org/apache/pinot/tools/admin/command/StartKafkaCommand.java
```
The diff looks good. Thanks for the fix!

Please update the commit message.
Also, i am not sure where (or even how) to document the fact that if multiple updates happen, not all of them will be taken. For now, we can add that as a part of the commit message at least, I suppose. thanks.
@fx19880617  any suggestions?
I feel it's better to use `getResourceAsStream` if it could read the schema file from `pinot-integration-tests` jar
These are incompatible changes with earlier version of Helix. You should keep the old one at least for one release _after_ introducing the new APIs, so as to allow users to migrate.
Also, when you finally remove the old APIs, do a major revision bump since that is a backward-incompatible change.

> How much time does this add? We have a 1 hr limit right? Should we remove kafka-0.9 at this point?

Please review new PR here: https://github.com/apache/incubator-pinot/pull/5045

This PR does consider the case when Helix transition to ONLINE comes.

There is only one host can win the change to commit. 
For the winner, it's ok to close the consumer since its consumption job is done. 
For the rest, they will get the Helix transition to ONLINE.
If it's needed to catch up with the offset, it's ok to close the consumer after they finished catching up; if it's needed to download the segment, the current consumer is also unnecessary to leave it open.

Thus, it's OK to close it before building or downloading the segment.

Addressed all the review comments. 
Circulated the detailed doc in community. We are all in agreement with the high level structure of FieldConfig. There is going to be follow-up work soon to deprecate and migrate -- the information is captured in the doc

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1PyULfbLOYa5OexZMqbP_MZgg-338flKETJOKWS5en3g/edit

> LGTM otherwise. Are we going to use this to replace some of the indexing config?

Yes exactly. Some parts of IndexingConfig like invertedIndexColumns, noDictionaryColumns, bloomFilterColumns etc will be gone and replaced by FieldConfig where the column's encoding and index info is self-contained and not spread throughout IndexingConfig.

TableConfig can then have a List<FieldConfig.

Please see here https://docs.google.com/document/d/1PyULfbLOYa5OexZMqbP_MZgg-338flKETJOKWS5en3g/edit

Done.. Thank you!

I still dont understand how this reduces ZK access. Correct me if I am wrong with the following description.

We used to fetch the propertystore table config all the time. Now, we do a Stat followed by a fetch if the stat does not match.

So, we have effectively increased the number of read calls to zk. 

Yes, we have reduced the overall volume of reads from ZK, but I am not sure that is a bottleneck we are facing. Our problem with ZK is on the write side.

OK, the resolution is that most of the time we don't need to fetch the table config. On clusters with 1000s of tables this change will reduce the volume of data pulled from zk each time we restart a broker.

> Do we need to handle the case that user only want alerts for SLA monitoring without any detection?

@vincentchenjl  Yes, we will. But this PR is only addressing the availability of data for detection jobs. In the next phase, we will have a DataSLACronScheduler which will allow users to define custom SLAs independent of detection.

@mcvsubbu , I have addressed the review comments:

Latest changes:

- Move the realtime state handler to a separate class RealtimeLuceneIndexRefreshState. This manages the global queue.
- The background task is started only if we have a TEXT index column.
- Other review comments
- Rebased on my [previous FieldConfig change](https://github.com/apache/incubator-pinot/pull/5006). Text index creation info for a column is now specified as part of FieldConfig.
- Moved index files under v3/

**Major TODO:**

Handle segment reload. Once this PR goes in, I will come up with a follow-up PR immediately to address that.

> Is this POC going to be merged, or are we going to split things as per the design doc?

The POC will remain but I will remove the non-controller changes from it. I will create separate PRs (one for server side and the other for validationManager ). Most of the reviews in this PR is about controller changes and I would like to keep them.

Other general points discussied:
* Disable TEXT_MATCH until we have implemented reload -- otherwise, adding a text index on a column (our primary use case) will not work 
* Remove the about-to-close boolean for now, keep it simple, work under a lock. It may be fine since destroy() is not a critical operation.
* Create the singleton from HelixServerStarter, and start it as well. 
* Handle the case when segments with text index may be moved away to another host. We don't want that the thread continues to poll in this case. One way is to introduce a condition variable on the length of the queue.

We had earlier decided to not support this feature on dictionary encoded columns to prevent memory overhead of creating dictionary for large text like string columns on which this index is enabled. 

Having said that, nothing in the future really prevents us from doing so. So ideally this index can co-exist with other indexes -- we can create a text index on a  STRING column which is dictionary encoded and also has native Pinot's inverted index.

For the initial implementation of this feature (call it v0/v1 release), we chose to have these restrictions. Eventually we can relax them.

> Why do you want to query it 2000 times. Can we break out once all docs are loaded?

If I wait for a longer duration for all the docs to be loaded (as we do in other integration tests), there is a good chance that most of realtime segments might have already been committed by that time. So the queries will go to the completed offline segments.

My goal with this test is to serve majority of the queries via realtime segments with text index and see an increasing number of hits as queries are run consecutively, documents are being ingested and realtime segments are refreshed in the background.

Since I don't know how many times this particular search string is present in the data (which is generated randomly), I can't really break out.

Updates:

- Treat newly added columns in the mutable segment as physical columns instead of virtual columns
- Refactor column provider, so the newly added columns and virtual columns ($segmentName, $hostName) can share utils to generate default null values
- For `select *` queries, we will drop columns with names starting with '$'

There is more to it than meets the eye. We dont want to just move this into the loop, Instead, we should emit the metrics if we are extending the consumption time and there were errors. Let us think about this a bit more. I think it is outside the loop for a reason.

> Thanks for the fix. @akshayrai .
> One question is: If users don't receive all of the alerts how do we let them know?
> Can we add something in the email email says these are only partial alerts and some alerts are not sent?

@xiaohui-sun 
This is a pretty interesting problem but notifying users is a bit non-trivial and tricky. Note that each dimension recipient is independent of each other (each dimension recipient receives a completely different email), and there is no point in notifying other dimension recipients about the error. We could probably send an error email to the specific concerned recipients which would be helpful even in other normal cases. For example, if the detection failed or our default subscription config has an issue then we can send an error email. We can discuss this further offline.

In addition to this, what I have been thinking for a while is that we introduce the concept of subscription health similar to detection health and use that to kind of track how it performs (maybe even make it part of the email).

Besides, this specific PR attempts to address this issue by logging and emitting metrics which can be tracked and hopefully we can introduce some more sophisticated offline validations on the config so that such things do not occur, at least not by misconfiguration.
